comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06]  Here's another theory ...Corner of King Street and Pitt Street looking West towards darling Harbour, possibly the first day of cable tram operation in September 1894. (The bunting looks pretty tatty for Federation, but willing to be proved wrong!). Cable cars were replaced by electric trams between 1902 and 1905.

Intrigued by the circle with the middle distance "VICTORIA THE ???" - can Records help us, do you have a higher res pic?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Sure can, I've replaced this with a larger version. Circle says:

"VICTORIA
THE GOOD"

--
AB

comment.author: 21647809@N04
27331537@N06
comment._content: Well thought out John. Yes the decorations do look too subdued for the Federation procession of 1 January 1901. But the year is correct, although the images was most likely taken in May. This image shows King Street decorated for the visit to Sydney of the Duke and Duchess of York (later George VI and Queen Elizabeth) on Monday 28 May 1901. They were in Australia to open the first Federal Parliament. Even this shot of King Street and the related image at State Library of New South Wales NSW which is Government Printing Office image St1782 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=175085 seem subdued when compared with decorations for the visit in other streets. This was because of the death of Queen Victoria on 22 January 1901. King Street was decorated as the 'Queen's Avenue' as it ran to the statue of Queen Victoria in Queen's Square. The 'Queen's Avenue' was designed as a memorial to Victoria and the decorations are accordingly muted. The memorial wreath, 15 feet wide, with the words 'Victoria the Good' hung across King Street and was made of everlasting flowers. Wreaths from NSW country towns hung from garlands strung between the venetian masts topped with silver crowns. The bunting was a suitable mourning colour of purple. The decorations are described in the Sydney Morning Herald Tuesday 28 May 1901 page 7 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14387711. Victoria's statue in Queen's Sqaure was also under-decorated by the standards of the time, with garlands and greenery as shown in Government Printing Office images St1779 and St1780 at the State Library of NSW acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=175082 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=175083 We will amend the title and add in the May 1901 date. Thank you for bringing it to our attention. JS

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06]

All makes eminent sense to me! They sure loved their parades and decorations in those days! But the opening of the Federal Parliament was pretty special! And what a great idea creating a street as a memorial to the late Monarch - King Street no less.  Thanks for the city history lesson! 

I hope all this wonderful material is being made available to schools so our youngsters appreciate the city they live in ... better still why not a Facebook site on the City's history?

JC
